title: UX: Show actionable flight details on Prices and Trips pages
description:
Currently both pages show summary data but lack actionable details:

**Prices page issues:**
- Shows only aggregate stats (low/current/trend)
- No actual flight options with dates, airlines, stops
- No way to click through to book the flight
- Should show top 3 recent options with booking links

**Trips page issues:**
- Deal matches show destination + price + match % but NO travel dates
- User can't see WHEN the flights are available
- Unclear that "Search Live Prices" actually searches Google Flights (vs just RSS deals)

**Required changes:**
1. Prices page: Add section showing top 3 flight options with full details + Google Flights booking link
2. Trips page: Show parsed_travel_dates in deal cards
3. Trips page: Better labeling to distinguish RSS deals vs live Google Flights search

title: Implement rolling-horizon price monitoring architecture
description:
## Problem
Current Trip Plan searching is a "snapshot refresh" approach that doesn't work well for long monitoring windows (1+ years). Google Flights only has data ~10 months out, so we need a smarter approach.

## Oracle's Recommended Architecture

### 1. Persistent Itinerary Queue ( table)
- Track every origin/destination/date combo to monitor
- Columns: 
- As time passes, new dates become bookable â†’ add to queue automatically

### 2. Append-Only Price Observations
- Never delete historical observations
- Each search adds observations, updates best price if lower
- Reuse  pattern with 

### 3. Priority-Based Sampling (Rate-Limit Friendly)
- 70% budget: Recheck current top K cheapest (validate deals still exist)
- 30% budget: Explore new date buckets for coverage
- Stratify bookable window by month, ensure at least 1 itinerary/bucket

### 4. Rolling Horizon Candidate Generation
- Each scheduler run: 
- Add new itinerary rows for dates that just became bookable
- Stop scheduling itineraries whose departure has passed

### 5. "Best Ever Still Valid" Materialized View
- Derive from observations: 
- Order by , take top N per destination
- Refresh after each run

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ]  table created with proper schema
- [ ] Itineraries auto-generated as dates become bookable
- [ ] Price observations stored append-only
- [ ] Priority sampling: recheck best deals + explore new dates
- [ ] Expired itineraries cleaned up (departure passed)
- [ ] UI shows "best ever" prices with freshness indicator
- [ ] Cap itineraries per plan to avoid explosion

## Effort
Medium (1-2 days)

title: Redesign Trip Planner as unified flight agent
description:
## Problem
Currently Trip Planner has a split experience:
- RSS deal matches shown in one section
- Google Flights search is separate manual action
- GF results aren't persisted - shown temporarily then lost
- No scheduled GF searches for Trip Plans

## User Vision
Trip Plan acts as an "agent" that:
1. Monitors ALL sources (Google Flights + any configured APIs + RSS)
2. Persists the BEST 3 matches from any source
3. Runs on schedule (based on check_frequency_hours)
4. Shows consolidated "Best Matches" prominently
5. User can check daily, eventually book when perfect match appears

## Solution
1. Create TripPlanMatch model to persist matches from any source
2. Add scheduled job for Trip Plan GF searches
3. Modify TripPlanSearchService to persist top matches
4. Update UI to show unified "Best Matches" section
5. Remove separate RSS vs GF paradigm

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Trip Plans search Google Flights on schedule
- [ ] Best 3-5 matches persisted per Trip Plan
- [ ] UI shows unified matches from all sources
- [ ] Each match has: source, price, dates, destination, booking link
- [ ] Matches update automatically based on check_frequency_hours
